comments.commentBody: HUED better pipe down John as the HISS from your comment is ECHOing all the way to CUBA...Who's the CADdish looking HOSEr you CHOSE for your avatar?

>>... the class of sixty-nine?

Weren't most yearbook photos in color by then? I actually found a few in color from elementary schools. I guess I went to a cheap high school!
Kiki, my actual photos were in color but the ones in the yearbook were all in black-and-white.  Color yearbook pages were much more expensive to produce than black-and-white ones.

Liz B,

That explains why some of my elementary school pictures were in color. We had no yearbooks in those schools.

It doesn't explain why my senior yearbook photo and the ones they sold me were all in B&W.

One of my favorite Beatles songs was "When I'm Sixty-Four" until I actually passed that age! I still play it on guitar, but rarely sing it anymore. Unfortunately, the opening to NORWEGIAN WOOD is so ingrained in my memory that it prevented today's puzzle from being a challenge at all.

I never did explain my current avatar that arose from last Sunday's puzzle. Remember the YEAR BOOK PHOTOGRAPH? I actually scanned that one from my senior high school year book after a futile search for a larger version.

Why is it not surprising that someone in a position of power who has not been seriously challenged for 40 years might abuse that position to enrich himself? New Yorkers need to pay more attention to who their representatives are in Albany. And the NY media haven't shown much interest in Teflon Sheldon's schemes either.
Believing that "one of us" refers to some ethnically or religiously defined subset of humanity is more damaging than anything Silver could have done.
Tort reform will never happen.  Too many lawyers in Albany making too much money from this stupid system.  We will all continue to be the victims.

The first thing that came to mind is a poem by a different "Shelley":

'My name is Ozymandias, king of kings:
Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!'
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away.

Like Ozymandias, this Shelly, a king of kings for so long, also leaves behind a colossal wreck: a toothless legislature rife with corruption, but slowly being bared for all to see.

TERM LIMITS!

Too much power for too long = corruption.

As Paul Mathis pointed out in his comment, with supporting
quotes from Keynes' "General Theory", an economy will
stabilize at a level consistent with the way in which it is being
managed. Thanks.

For us now the economic component of our economy that
we call Fiscal Policy is being held captive by the Conservative
political element of our body politic to prevent any political
advantage that might accrue to the current President and
his party.

All that could be done with Monetary policy has probably
been done.

Unless politicians are elected who will implement a Fiscal
Policy that has a goal of stimulating the economy then the
we will probably only experience economic stagnation or
decline.

If the current level of Fiscal and Monetary Policy are
to be the new norm then the best we could hope for
is some event which forces the elected politicians to
implement levels of Fiscal expenditure they currently will
not do.

This sounds way too much like the Great Depression/WWII
scenario.

The next 60 games are going to be torture. The fawning and accolades will be non-stop, while the Lakers sleepwalk toward another lottery pick. Meanwhile, Kobe will continue to stand around and hoist up perimeter bricks. Thank god he's gone ... well not yet.
Added corn and doubled the garlic! nom nom

Ed, I suppose you can find evidence for just about anything especially if it's a nebulous theory, even if it is based on overwhelming evidence. You go for preponderance of evidence, or beyond a REASONABLE doubt, not beyond any shadow of doubt.

Just because we exhale CO2, which plants use to synthesize starch & other carbohydrates, which in turn we eat, doesn't mean that humungous CO2 emissions wouldn't cause global warming.

Sen. Jim Inhofe of Oklahoma denied global warming on a cold day in Washington by throwing a snowball! That's his evidence. When some glaciers are left in the arctic, even if much of it has been gone, you can say, "See, is this Global Warming? Where's the warmth?"

There is a "Flat Earth" society. Then the UFO group. The list goes on.

I just had a great idea to solve global warming. Scientists are using computer models to predict the future of the climate 100 years out. Climate is a complex system. Climate is much more complex than an NFL season. The scientists could use their computer models to predict the winner of the Super Bowl and then bet big in Vegas. They could use their computer models to predict who will win the World Series, the PGA Tour, the Grand Prix and the World Cup. They could make billions, probably a couple billion on Fantasy Football alone. No need to raise our taxes. They could then use all this money to build windmills and solar farms and buy everyone a Prius. Problem solved.
or Congress...
Could this be the beginning of another series, John?
Another alum from the class of sixty-nine?
Sorry but 1 °C global temperature increase is a lot!  As for tropical cyclones, consider the western Pacific over this century...

Many of the events in your list occurred long ago--billions of years ago.
Petrified palm tree seedlings have been found in rock formations in the Grand Canyon.
Let me assure you Florida has always experienced heavy precip and flooding.
Just come down and experience our monsoons between May and October.
I do believe Miami Beach might be doomed, however, both from an antiquated storm water system and the sell out to condo developers. Miami needs more condos like Carters needs pills.

Larry:

Nope. Sadly, we will all (including you) be affected by the consequences of a massive push to keep people ignorant and incurious, while stoking their fear and dislike of people different from themselves, and their reliance on magic thinking. Sort of like: "don't let government mess with my Medicare"
http://climate.nasa.gov/

All this is happening now, and there's plenty of evidence. Politics won't fix our planet, which we are using as a dump and exploiting at a scale never before seen. There is no Planet B.
http://sealevel.climatecentral.org/

whole lotta denial going on (unapologetic for using plain English to described it). Here's what's being denied:

These impacts will continue to intensify, grow ever more costly and damaging, and increasingly affect the entire planet — including you, your community, and your family.

* Accelerating sea level rise and increased coastal flooding
* Longer and more damaging wildfire seasons
* More frequent and intense heat waves
* National landmarks at risk
* Widespread forest death in the Rocky Mountains
* Costly and growing health impacts
* An increase in extreme weather events
* Heavier precipitation and flooding
* More severe droughts in some areas
* Increased pressure on groundwater supplies
* Growing risks to our electricity supply
* Destabilization of seasons
* Melting ice
* Disruptions to food supplies

Surely, exploiting one's fellow man, which is what capitalism, free trade and globalisation are all about, and which most economists seek to rationalise and justify, because they personally benefit from it, cannot be right - or sustainable.

We need to face up to the fact that the primary purpose of the state and the socio-economic order it provides the legal framework for is not to severe society, as we are taught, but to facilitate its SELF-exploitation, to the personal advantage of its ruling elites and favoured (especially wealthy and academic) clients, at the expense (and ultimate self-destruction) of society at large. This is why all past civilisations have declined and disappeared.

Anarchists were right in their assessment of the state, but wrong in believing that one could simply do away with it. Clearly, one can't. All any revolution has achieved is to replace one ruling elite and its favoured clients with another.

We urgently need to radically reform both state and socio-economic order. Trouble is, everyone who is anyone in society, with any power or influence, is well served by the status quo, with no interest in radical change - except that its non-sustainability and rapidly approaching collapse will impact everyone, including their own children and grandchildren. Therein lies our only hope. But before we can effect change, we need a far better understanding of our situation: http://philosopherkin.blogspot.co.uk/2012/04/civilisation-evolutionary-c...

.
Good anagramming. Once again, I'm not catching the preveal. No matter. I'm more curious about why your guys's career seems to have ended after he finished the work referred to in the grid. It's also funny how his name is similar to someone else's but there's apparently no relation.

Caveat: If you bounce a baseball against a wall made of NORWEGIAN WOOD, it may not bounce back the way you like it to.
Oven temp?

Swiftly?
Getting caught after decades of doing dirty deeds ain't "being punished swiftly" in my book. Actually, this looks more like crime does pay, for almost a lifetime anyway.

>>... the class of sixty-nine?

Weren't most yearbook photos in color by then? I actually found a few in color from elementary schools. I guess I went to a cheap high school!

Illinois and Louisiana used to be infamous for the corruption of their state legislatures, but I suspect many (most?) state governments are awash in kickbacks, cronyism, and graft. I wonder what tools are needed to bring better checks and balances to the states.

Commenters have mentioned better civil tort law, making legislator jobs full-time (while banning outside income), and term limits. That last one doesn't appeal to me: it overrules the will of voters and reduces the number of experienced veteran lawmakers - many of whom are excellent.

A better reform is to end the gerrymander, with districts drawn by bipartisan commissions.

Belinda, DeBlasio has appointed the most tenant-friendly Rent Guidelines Board in decades, granting us the lowest rent increases on rent stabilized apartments in decades.
So, we still have a voice.
Thank God for DeBlasio!
Shocking, absolutely shocking that a member of the NY state legislature was found guilty of corruption. Who could have imagined such a scenario?
